lens.lens_summary: Jason's call reveals a traditional landlord whose real-world expectations (in-person showings, income verification, furniture negotiation) clash with Split Lease's streamlined digital model, while Cagan's Inspired framework exposes this as a product/market fit gap where the platform has not yet discovered the right product for the skeptical-but-willing host who needs to see the offline experience validated before trusting the online process.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Jason was found through Craigslist, meaning Split Lease's discovery channel is piggy-backing on a platform Jason already trusts for listing his property. Bryant references this explicitly at 00:00: 'This is Brian from Craigslist.' Jason did not discover Split Lease organically; he was intercepted on a channel he was already using. Cagan's framework (Ch. 3) emphasizes that startups must race to product/market fit, and the discovery phase reveals that Split Lease is currently in a 'concierge discovery' mode -- manually sourcing hosts from competitor platforms rather than attracting them through product-led discovery. This is viable for learning but does not scale. The host's first impression of Split Lease is mediated entirely by a human (Bryant), not the product itself.

user_state.emotional_state: Neutral-to-curious. Jason answered the call and engaged willingly ('Hey, this is Jason' at 00:00), suggesting he is open to inquiries about his listing. No defensiveness detected at this stage.
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason knows nothing about Split Lease at this point. He listed on Craigslist and is receiving what he perceives as a response to that listing. His mental model is 'someone responding to my Craigslist ad,' not 'a platform is recruiting me.'
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing. Jason is passively receiving information. He has made no commitment to Split Lease and does not yet understand what it is.
user_state.data_available: Craigslist listing details (price, location, furnishing status). Jason's phone number. No platform profile, no account, no digital footprint with Split Lease.

reasons: Jason does not know what Split Lease is -- the entire discovery depends on Bryant successfully explaining the value proposition in real-time
If Bryant's pitch does not resonate immediately, Jason can simply hang up and continue with his Craigslist listing
Cagan warns (Ch. 6) that ideas sourced externally (here, hosts sourced from Craigslist) are not the best source of product-market fit -- the host has no intrinsic motivation to use Split Lease
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 00:00-00:23: Bryant must explain both who he is AND what Split Lease is in the first 23 seconds. The fact that he leads with the guests (Ariel and Amber) rather than the platform suggests the platform itself is not the draw -- the matched guests are.

key_quotes.quote: This is Brian from Craigslist.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant anchors himself to Craigslist, not Split Lease, revealing that the platform's brand has no independent discovery value for hosts yet.

key_quotes.quote: I actually work for a company called split lease, which is how I got connected with Ariel and Amber.
key_quotes.relevance: Split Lease is introduced as a middleman explanation, not as a value proposition. The host hears 'company that connected me with these specific people,' not 'platform that solves your vacancy problem.'

key_quotes.quote: A startup is still trying to invent a product that can drive a viable business... Nothing else matters until you invent a strong product that meets initial market needs.
key_quotes.relevance: Split Lease's manual Craigslist outreach is classic pre-product/market-fit behavior. The product has not yet replaced the human in discovery.

evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: The evaluation phase in Jason's call is dominated by a risk assessment conversation that happens entirely through human mediation. Bryant proactively addresses Jason's core concerns: guest vetting (00:46), rent guarantee (00:46), deposit matching (01:54), and the rental agreement structure (02:12). Jason evaluates by asking pointed questions: total income (06:14), lease term (06:43), and whether guests will see the place (10:18). Cagan's Ch. 6 critique of the waterfall model is directly relevant: Split Lease's evaluation is currently a 'requirements gathering' call where the agent discovers what the host needs. But Cagan argues the best product teams tackle risks (value, usability, feasibility, viability) upfront in discovery. Jason's questions reveal unaddressed product risks: the platform apparently has no mechanism for in-person viewings, income transparency, or furniture negotiation -- all critical to this host's evaluation.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautiously engaged but increasingly skeptical. Jason asks direct, practical questions (income, term, showings) and pushes back on the no-showing norm at 10:50: 'sounds a bit odd that they don't want to see the place before they move in.'
user_state.knowledge_level: Rapidly increasing through the call. By 02:51, Jason understands the deposit structure, payment guarantee, and agreement framework. However, his knowledge is entirely verbal -- nothing written, nothing on-screen, nothing he can verify independently.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating seriously. Jason is engaging with specifics (parking, furniture, cleaning) which signals genuine consideration, but he has not committed to anything.
user_state.data_available: Verbal information from Bryant about guest vetting, income ranges, deposit matching. No documentation yet -- Bryant promises to email after the call (09:27-10:01).

reasons: Jason's strongest objection -- that guests should see the place before signing -- is unresolved. Bryant sidesteps it at 10:22 by saying 'typically we don't show the place beforehand' which directly contradicts Jason's experience as a landlord who has done 6 showings
Jason explicitly flags this as unusual at 10:50 and 12:35-12:52, repeating his concern twice, indicating it is a real blocker
The income information is not available during the call (06:21: 'I'd have to look that up'), leaving a key evaluation criterion unanswered
Cagan's framework: this is a value risk -- the product has not proven it solves the host's real problems (trust through physical verification, income transparency)
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 12:35-12:52: 'A lot of people are like, this just sounds weird to me that they want to sign a lease without seeing it.' Jason is projecting his landlord norms onto the situation and finding Split Lease's model deficient.

key_quotes.quote: I've been doing showings. It sounds a bit odd that they don't want to see the place before they move in.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the central evaluation friction: Jason's landlord mental model requires in-person verification. Split Lease's model bypasses it. This is not a UX problem -- it is a product/market fit gap.

key_quotes.quote: They've both been vetted. We verified employment credit and previous landlord references as well. And also we guarantee the rent payment to you as the landlord.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant front-loads the trust signals (vetting + guarantee), which is good product discovery practice per Cagan -- address the biggest risk first.

key_quotes.quote: What's a total income between both of them? ... I'd have to look that up. I don't have it handy with me right now.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent cannot answer a basic evaluation question in real-time. Per Cagan (Ch. 6), this is a failure of discovery preparation -- the team should know what data the host needs before the call.

key_quotes.quote: This model leads to stakeholder-driven products and sales-driven specials... this is not the source of our best product ideas. Another consequence is the lack of team empowerment.
key_quotes.relevance: The current evaluation is entirely agent-driven (stakeholder-driven in Cagan's terms). The product team has no direct signal from Jason's evaluation concerns because they flow through Bryant, not through the platform.

onboarding.what_this_lens_reveals: The onboarding phase is invisible in Jason's call because it has not happened yet. The call ends with Bryant promising to send an email (10:01, 13:59) and Jason providing his email address (09:43). The transition from evaluation to onboarding is entirely dependent on a follow-up email. Cagan's framework highlights this as a critical gap: the best product companies ensure that the transition from discovery to the product experience is seamless. Jason's onboarding will happen asynchronously, after the call, when his engagement level is lower and competing priorities (his 6 other showings, his kitchen repairs, his deep cleaning plans) will consume his attention. The existing library (works-004: Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust) already identifies this as the highest-risk transition. Jason's call reinforces this with even more evidence: he is a hands-on landlord who expects physical, in-person processes, making the digital transition even more jarring.

user_state.emotional_state: Post-call fade. Jason was engaged during the conversation but will experience natural attention decay before the onboarding email arrives. His last words (13:59) are polite but noncommittal: 'Thanks a lot. Have a good rest of your weekend.'
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason understands the verbal pitch but has seen nothing in writing. He has no account, no login, no visual reference for what the platform looks like. His only concrete next step is 'expect an email.'
user_state.commitment_level: Low. Jason is one of multiple options: he mentions doing 6 showings and recently having 2 more. Split Lease's guests are considering other places too (13:26). Neither side is committed.
user_state.data_available: Jason's email (jasonglee@gmail.com), phone number, property details from Craigslist listing, verbal conversation notes from Bryant. No platform profile exists.

reasons: Jason has 6 prior showings and active traditional leads -- he may fill the apartment through conventional means before onboarding begins
The email follow-up introduces a time gap where Jason's engagement decays
Jason's unresolved concern about in-person showings may harden into a rejection during the gap
Cagan (Ch. 3): 'You are in a race to achieve product/market fit before you run out of money' -- similarly, Split Lease is in a race to onboard Jason before he finds a tenant through Craigslist
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 13:31: 'I didn't have done six total showings, but four of them were like a month ago... recently I only did about two showings.' Jason is actively showing the apartment to traditional prospects. The onboarding email competes with real-world alternatives.

key_quotes.quote: Could I get your email, send over some information to you after this call? JasongLee@gmail.com.
key_quotes.relevance: The entire onboarding hinges on this email exchange. There is no instant activation, no link shared during the call, no immediate next step that keeps Jason engaged.

key_quotes.quote: I'll follow up with an email shortly. And like I said, if you have questions for me, text email either way, anytime works.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant promises proximity but the platform is absent. The onboarding is entirely human-dependent with no product touchpoint.

key_quotes.quote: Technology-powered products do not need to be purely digital. Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences.
key_quotes.relevance: Cagan's insight is directly applicable: Jason's onboarding should blend the offline trust built in the call with an immediate online activation, not treat them as sequential stages.

listing_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Jason's call reveals significant complexity in listing creation that the platform must handle. His apartment has a nuanced furniture situation: a bed, a futon of questionable quality (08:19: 'it can be flipped on, but it's not the highest quality'), 4 tables/desks (11:52: 'there's actually too many tables'), and furniture that is difficult to move due to building security (08:55-09:27). He is also planning a deep cleaning (11:17) and has recently resolved kitchen issues (13:31). These details represent the gap between a Craigslist listing (static photos + price) and what Split Lease needs (dynamic, negotiable, condition-aware listing). Cagan's Ch. 6 critique of the waterfall process is relevant: listing creation should not be a one-time form submission but an iterative discovery process where the host's real situation is captured accurately. The current process requires Bryant to manually relay these nuances.

user_state.emotional_state: Pragmatic and detail-oriented. Jason volunteers specific information about furniture condition, building logistics, and cleaning plans without prompting, suggesting he takes property management seriously.
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason knows his property intimately (parking patterns, furniture inventory, building rules, cleaning needs) but does not know how to translate this knowledge into a Split Lease listing format.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditionally willing. Jason is open to leaving furniture and adjusting the space for guests, but this is contingent on knowing what guests actually need.
user_state.data_available: Craigslist photos exist. Detailed verbal inventory from the call: bed, futon, 4 tables/desks, furnished capability, no pets allowed, parking details, kitchen recently repaired.

reasons: The gap between Jason's detailed physical knowledge and a digital listing form could be frustrating if the form does not capture his nuances (furniture condition, willingness to adjust)

Jason's deep cleaning and furniture adjustment depend on knowing the tenant -- he cannot finalize the listing until the match is confirmed (11:17-11:38: 'I haven't decided... it depends on the tenant')

Cagan's root cause #1: stakeholder-driven products miss real user needs. If the listing form was designed without input from hosts like Jason, it will miss the furniture-negotiation and condition-transparency needs
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 08:36-09:27: Jason's extended discussion of the futon's cleanliness, the mattress quality, and the logistics of moving furniture through building security reveals listing complexity that no standard form captures.

key_quotes.quote: It can be flipped on, but it's not the highest quality. I can let them know.
key_quotes.relevance: Furniture condition is a listing attribute that matters but is rarely captured in property listing platforms. Jason wants transparency about quality.

key_quotes.quote: There's actually too many tables. So I can just move out a couple of the tables. There's four tables and desks. Really need all of that.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing is not static -- Jason is willing to customize the space. The platform needs to support configurable furnished listings, not just 'furnished: yes/no.'

key_quotes.quote: Behind every great product is someone who led the team to combine technology and design to solve real customer problems in a way that meets the needs of the business.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing creation challenge is a real customer problem: hosts have nuanced, negotiable property configurations that static forms cannot capture. Solving this is a product discovery opportunity.

pricing.what_this_lens_reveals: Pricing in Jason's call is straightforward on the surface -- $2,975/month rent plus one month security deposit (01:17-01:42) -- but Bryant introduces a pricing innovation that differentiates Split Lease: deposit matching (01:54: 'split lease matches the deposit as well, so it'd be two months'). Jason also learns about the supplemental agreement between Split Lease and the landlord covering guaranteed payments (02:12). The pricing is presented conversationally and accepted without resistance, suggesting the price point is within market expectations. However, there is no discussion of Split Lease's fee structure from the host's perspective. Cagan's business case critique (Ch. 6) applies: the pricing model's viability depends on whether the unit economics work at $2,975/month with matched deposits and guaranteed payments. Jason does not ask about platform fees, which could mean either the fee is zero for hosts or Bryant intentionally avoided the topic.

user_state.emotional_state: Comfortable. Jason confirms the rent and deposit amounts matter-of-factly (01:42: 'Just a security deposit. Standard in New York is one month.'). No pricing anxiety detected.
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason understands his own pricing ($2,975 + 1 month deposit) and the deposit matching concept. He does not appear to understand Split Lease's revenue model or whether he pays any platform fees.
user_state.commitment_level: Price-stable. Jason is not negotiating on price, suggesting the rental amount is firm and he expects the market to meet it.
user_state.data_available: Monthly rent: $2,975. Security deposit: 1 month. Split Lease matched deposit: 1 additional month. Garage parking: $500+/month (context for overall cost-of-living in the area).

reasons: Pricing is not a friction point in this call -- Jason's concerns are about trust and process, not money
The deposit matching is perceived as a bonus, not a cost
The only pricing risk is undisclosed: if Split Lease charges host-side fees that Jason learns about later, it could feel like a bait-and-switch
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 01:54: Bryant presents deposit matching as a benefit ('which I just wanted to let you know'), and Jason does not object. Pricing frictions are absent from this call.

key_quotes.quote: Was there a damage deposit? Just a security deposit. New York is one month, standard in New York is one month.
key_quotes.relevance: Jason frames the deposit in familiar NYC landlord terms. The platform's pricing language must match this familiarity.

key_quotes.quote: Split lease matches the deposit as well. So it'd be two months, which we would hold.
key_quotes.relevance: Deposit matching is a concrete differentiator that resonates with risk-averse landlords. This is a product feature worth surfacing prominently.

key_quotes.quote: It comes down to knowing two things about each idea: (1) How much money or value will this generate? and (2) How much money or time will this cost?
key_quotes.relevance: Cagan's business case framework applies to Jason's pricing evaluation: he implicitly calculates value (guaranteed rent + double deposit) vs. cost (unknown platform fees + process friction). The value side is clear; the cost side is opaque.

proposal_mgmt.what_this_lens_reveals: The proposal management phase is partially visible in Jason's call. Bryant is effectively presenting a pre-formed proposal: two matched guests (Ariel & Amber), income above $80K each, 6-month initial term with possibility of extension, March start date, furnished preference. Jason evaluates this proposal through his landlord lens, asking about income verification (06:14), term flexibility (06:43), move-in timing (07:42), furniture needs (07:55-08:14), and the critical question of whether guests will view the space (10:18). Cagan's critique of the waterfall model applies directly: the proposal is assembled by Bryant (the 'product manager' in this analogy) based on stakeholder input, then presented to Jason. But Jason's real concerns -- showings, cleaning timeline, furniture configuration -- are not part of the standard proposal structure. The proposal addresses financial terms but not the operational and trust terms that Jason actually cares about.

user_state.emotional_state: Engaged but operating in landlord-evaluation mode. Jason asks questions a traditional landlord would ask (income, showings, term). He is not yet in 'Split Lease mode' -- he is evaluating this as he would any prospective tenant.
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason understands the financial proposal (rent, deposit, term) but lacks information on the operational proposal (how showings work, how cleaning is coordinated, how furniture decisions are communicated).
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating the proposal but not ready to accept. The call ends without a yes or no -- Bryant will follow up by email.
user_state.data_available: Guest names, approximate income ranges (over $80K each, exact figures unavailable during call), desired term (6 months to start), desired start date (March), furnishing preference.

reasons: The proposal is incomplete from Jason's perspective: he needs income verification, a showing option, and furniture/cleaning coordination before he can decide
Jason's guests are also considering other places (13:20-13:26), meaning the proposal may expire naturally
The proposal exists only verbally -- there is no written proposal for Jason to review, compare, or share with anyone else

Cagan (Ch. 6): the waterfall model fails because by the time the product reaches the customer, it is too late to discover it does not meet their needs. Similarly, by the time Bryant's email arrives, Jason may have moved on
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 13:20-13:26: 'Also, I mean, they're considering other places as well, right? Yes. Yep. They're taking a look at a couple other places.' Both sides have alternatives, creating time pressure the current process does not address.

key_quotes.quote: They're looking for something long term, like potentially over one year. I think probably six months is something that they could do, with like possibility to extend. They were somewhat hesitant to committing to like a year upfront.
key_quotes.relevance: Term negotiation happens conversationally. The platform's proposal management must support this kind of flexible, conditional term structuring -- not just fixed options.

key_quotes.quote: They're considering other places as well, right? Yes.
key_quotes.relevance: Both parties are in multi-option evaluation mode. The proposal management system must create urgency and clarity to prevent mutual attrition.

key_quotes.quote: It all starts with ideas... There is always a ton of things from different parts of the business that need to be done. Companies want to prioritize these ideas into a roadmap.
key_quotes.relevance: The proposal is itself a 'roadmap' of ideas (term, price, furnishing) that needs prioritization based on what matters most to the host. Jason prioritizes trust (showings) over financials (price), but the proposal leads with financials.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: The active lease phase is not directly addressed in Jason's call, as no lease has been signed. However, several forward-looking signals in the call reveal what Jason would need during an active lease. Jason describes detailed parking logistics (03:15-05:14) that guests would need to know and navigate daily. He mentions the futon's cleanliness concern (08:36: 'people come in and they're like, oh, there's like a dirt stain') which signals he anticipates guest complaints. He plans a deep cleaning (11:17) but has not decided on the scope because it depends on whether the space is furnished. Building security constraints on furniture movement (08:55-09:27) suggest logistics issues during the lease. Cagan's principle that technology-powered products are 'blends of online and offline experiences' (Ch. 2) is highly relevant: the active lease is where online (platform communication, payment tracking) and offline (parking, cleaning, furniture) experiences converge, and Jason's call shows the offline complexity is substantial.

user_state.emotional_state: Not applicable -- Jason has not entered this phase. But his detailed knowledge of the property's operational realities (parking schedules, cleaning needs, furniture constraints) suggests he would be a proactive, detail-oriented host during an active lease.
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason has deep operational knowledge of his property and neighborhood. He lacks knowledge of how Split Lease manages active leases (payment tracking, communication tools, issue resolution).
user_state.data_available: Detailed parking information (street cleaning schedule, garage pricing, time-of-day availability patterns), furniture inventory, building rules (no pets, security for furniture moves), kitchen repair history.

reasons: Jason's operational expectations (cleanliness standards, furniture condition transparency, parking guidance) may not be met by the platform's active lease tools
If guest complaints arise about issues Jason flagged during the call (futon quality, dirt stains), and the platform does not have a pre-agreed resolution mechanism, trust erodes
Cagan's insight: products fail when they solve the wrong problem. The active lease problem for Jason is not payment (that is guaranteed) -- it is operational coordination and property care
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 08:36-08:55: 'I don't realize that people come in and they're like, oh, they're like, there's like a dirt stain near or whatever it may be.' Jason is pre-emptively worrying about guest perception during the active lease.

key_quotes.quote: Parking battery park city, the parking is quite tough because it's the business district... street cleaning once a week... sometimes it'll take an hour if it's maybe Saturday night.
key_quotes.relevance: This level of neighborhood knowledge needs to be captured in a house manual or active lease communication tool. It is critical operational information that lives only in Jason's head.

key_quotes.quote: People come in and they're like, oh, there's like a dirt stain... but they could also get another bed or another type of thing to put on top of it.
key_quotes.relevance: Jason anticipates guest complaints and suggests solutions. The active lease phase needs a mechanism for hosts to proactively set expectations about known property imperfections.

key_quotes.quote: Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences -- like getting a ride or a room for the night.
key_quotes.relevance: Cagan explicitly references Airbnb-style marketplaces. The active lease is where the online-offline blend must work seamlessly, and Jason's call shows the offline side has substantial complexity.

retention.what_this_lens_reveals: Retention is not explicitly discussed in the call, but structural signals point to both retention risks and opportunities. Jason mentions he has done 6 showings and recently resolved kitchen issues (13:31), indicating he invests effort in maintaining and improving his property -- a positive retention signal if the platform rewards this behavior. However, Jason's resistance to the no-showing norm (10:50, 12:35) suggests that if this first experience does not align with his landlord expectations, he will not return. Cagan's Ch. 5 on enterprise companies warns about the 'slow death spiral' where companies fail to consistently innovate for existing users. For Split Lease, the retention equivalent is: if Jason's first guest experience is mediocre (due to unresolved issues flagged in the call), he will revert to Craigslist rather than give the platform a second chance. The platform must also solve a Cagan-identified scaling challenge: Jason is a single-property host, so retention economics differ from multi-property hosts.

user_state.emotional_state: Not applicable -- pre-lease. But Jason's personality suggests he will form strong opinions about the experience. He is direct ('sounds a bit odd,' 'that just sounds weird to me') and will not be diplomatically quiet about problems.
user_state.knowledge_level: Jason has strong Craigslist-based retention comparison points. If Split Lease's end-to-end experience is not clearly better than Craigslist's, he has no reason to stay.
user_state.commitment_level: Zero platform loyalty. Jason found Split Lease through Craigslist and can return to Craigslist at any time with zero switching cost.
user_state.data_available: No retention data -- this is the first interaction. The only forward indicator is Jason's willingness to engage in a 14-minute call, which suggests he is invested enough to give the platform a fair evaluation.

reasons: Zero switching cost: Jason's Craigslist listing presumably still exists. If Split Lease does not convert this lead, he simply continues with his existing channel
Jason's unresolved objection about showings could become a narrative he tells other landlords ('they wanted my tenants to sign without seeing the place'), creating negative word-of-mouth

Cagan (Ch. 5): 'Several large established companies have already embarked on a slow death spiral. They dedicate themselves entirely to leveraging value created years or even decades before.' If Split Lease does not continuously improve the host experience based on feedback from hosts like Jason, it will lose them to platforms that do
dropout_risk.evidence: jason-call.txt, 13:31: Jason's 6 showings and kitchen repairs demonstrate he is an active, improving landlord. He will compare Split Lease's service quality against his own standards of property management effort.

key_quotes.quote: Let me know if they want to see it because... a lot of people are like, this just sounds weird to me that they want to sign a lease without seeing it.
key_quotes.relevance: If this concern is never resolved, it becomes Jason's lasting impression of Split Lease -- a platform with weird practices -- which poisons retention before the first lease even begins.

key_quotes.quote: I had done some, a little bit of repair work in the kitchen... I resolved most of that stuff.
key_quotes.relevance: Jason invests in his property. A platform that recognizes and rewards this investment (through better guest matches, higher visibility, host ratings) creates retention. One that treats all hosts equally does not.

key_quotes.quote: Strong technology product companies know they must ensure consistent product innovation. This means constantly creating new value for their customers and for their business.
key_quotes.relevance: Retention requires continuous value creation. For Jason, value = better guests than Craigslist delivers, less hassle than self-managing showings, and the deposit/payment guarantee. If any of these degrade, he leaves.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Traditional Landlord Mental Model vs. the Platform Model: Jason operates with deeply ingrained landlord expectations (in-person showings, direct income verification, hands-on furniture negotiation) that Split Lease's streamlined digital model does not accommodate. This mismatch recurs in every phase where Jason's expectations meet the platform's assumptions.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: jason-call.txt, 10:50: 'sounds a bit odd that they don't want to see the place'; 06:14: direct income question; 11:52: furniture adjustment discussion. Cagan Ch. 6: product initiatives fail when they solve problems the customer did not ask to have solved. Jason did not ask for a no-showing process -- he asked for vetted tenants.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Human Mediation Dependency: The entire host journey currently depends on Bryant. Discovery is Bryant calling. Evaluation is Bryant answering questions. Onboarding is Bryant sending an email. Proposal management is Bryant relaying terms. The platform is absent from every phase in this call. Cagan's Inspired framework would classify this as pre-product/market-fit behavior where the 'concierge' approach reveals what the product must eventually do, but the product itself does not yet do it.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: jason-call.txt: Bryant is the sole interface throughout the 14-minute call. The word 'platform' or 'website' is never mentioned. Cagan Ch. 3 (line ~241): 'The few that succeeded are generally those that are really good at product discovery.' The call IS product discovery -- but the insights must flow back into the product.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Offline Complexity Unaddressed by Online Tools: Jason's property has operational complexity (parking schedules, furniture condition nuances, building security rules, cleaning logistics) that exists in his head and in conversation but has no platform representation. This pattern affects listing creation (how to capture it), active lease (how to communicate it), and retention (whether the platform earns the right to manage it).
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: jason-call.txt, 03:15-05:14: 3-minute parking discussion covering street cleaning schedules, time-of-day availability, garage pricing, and historical patterns. jason-call.txt, 08:36-09:27: furniture condition, mattress logistics, building security constraints. Cagan Ch. 2 (line ~221): 'Many of the best examples today are blends of online and offline experiences.' The blend is not yet built.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Unanswered Questions as Product Gaps: Several of Jason's questions went unanswered during the call (exact combined income at 06:21, whether guests will see the place at 10:22, detailed cleaning coordination at 11:17-11:44). Each unanswered question represents a data point the platform should have surfaced proactively. Cagan's top-10 root causes of failure (Ch. 6) include 'the fatal flaw in business cases' where teams cannot know the answers to key questions upfront. Here, the questions are knowable -- they just were not prepared.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: jason-call.txt, 06:21: 'I'd have to look that up. I don't have it handy with me right now.' jason-call.txt, 10:22: 'typically actually we don't show the place beforehand.' jason-call.txt, 11:17-11:44: cleaning timeline left unresolved.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Competitive Alternatives Create Time Pressure at Every Phase: Jason has Craigslist, his own showing pipeline (6 showings), and traditional landlord channels. The guests have other places they are looking at. This dual-sided optionality means every phase has a ticking clock: if the platform does not move the host forward quickly, a competing alternative will capture them. Cagan (Ch. 3) frames this as the startup funding runway -- Split Lease has a 'conversion runway' with each host that is burning down.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: jason-call.txt, 13:20-13:26: 'They're considering other places as well, right? Yes.' jason-call.txt, 13:31: 'I had done six total showings.' Cagan Ch. 3: 'You are in a race to achieve product/market fit before you run out of money.' Substitute 'each host's patience' for 'money.'

sources_consulted: jason-call.txt: Full transcript (14-minute call between Bryant and Jason, Battery Park City landlord). Extracted: property details ($2,975/mo, furnished 1BR), host concerns (showings, income verification, furniture condition, parking), behavioral signals (traditional landlord mental model, multiple competing prospects), and specific quotes on evaluation friction.

inspired-product-discovery.txt: Marty Cagan's Inspired (Portuguese translation), Chapters 1-6. Extracted: product/market fit framework (Ch. 3), startup-to-scale trajectory (Ch. 4-5), root causes of failed product initiatives including stakeholder-driven roadmaps and unknowable business cases (Ch. 6), technology-powered products as online-offline blends (Ch. 2), and the principle that behind every great product is someone solving real customer problems (Ch. 1).
journey-types.json: Host journey phase definitions and key concerns. Used to structure the phase-by-phase analysis and ensure all 8 phases are addressed.

library/elements.json (first 200 lines): Existing elements works-001 through works-004 reviewed. Noted strong coverage on evaluation-to-onboarding transitions (works-001, works-004), cognitive depletion across phases (works-002), and platform-vs-conversation speed matching (works-003). All existing elements are based on the andreas-call + kahneman lens. This new lens (jason-call + inspired) provides complementary evidence on the same transitions but adds new dimensions: the traditional landlord mental model, offline operational complexity, and competitive alternative pressure.
